What is included in the CIHM (formerly known as complementary and alternative medicine or CAM) disciplines ranges from acupuncture and East Asian medicine, to chiropractic, to naturopathic medicine, to massage therapy to Ayurvedic medicine to mindfulness practices, diet therapies, herbal medicine and more. This chapter presents a global overview of complementary and integrative health and medicine, the implementation of governmental recognition and regulation of CIHM, and World Health Organization policies covering its modalities. The Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine 2009 BMC Complementary and Alternative Medicine 2015 Alternative healing, including spiritual healing, unconventional, traditional/folk, and complementary medical treatments, is an increasingly relevant health-care resource in contemporary health-care systems, and a broad, constantly changing, and heterogeneous field of medical pluralism. Some suggestions for classifying spiritual healing as presented in the academic and gray literature are summarized and discussed. The findings are interpreted in terms of the paradigm of alternative modernities. In the direction of, but also in addition to, this paradigm, magic is introduced as a concept to denote certain highly ambiguous occurrences in the alternative modern. Magic is still very much alive and not easy to identify merely as a counterpart of rational, knowledge generating, disembodying modernity. In this setting, spiritual healing might be seen as a form of magical self-care. Magic is neither modern nor traditional nor irrational per se, but has to be contextualized and described in terms of characteristics like holistic diagnosis, interpersonal congruence, the imaginations of agency, and efficacy.
